pullRequest.body:
The file in this PR constructs all possible matroids that have only one base (these are trivial to describe), and gives some API. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Thanks, @kmill ! 

I am a little confused as to why this passes CI, though - in the line below, this file uses the old symbol for matroid duality. Since I submitted it, the symbol has changed to another unicode star (#12431). Does CI somehow know that the symbol should be changed? 

`def freeOn (E : Set α) : Matroid α := (loopyOn E)﹡`
I think it's a function of this PR not having merged master, so the old symbol still works. If we sent it to bors, it would fail since bors merges the PR into master before building.

> I think it's a function of this PR not having merged master, so the old symbol still works. If we sent it to bors, it would fail since bors merges the PR into master before building.

So I should merge master and fix, I assume. I've failed spectacularly when I've tried this before, and had hundreds of changes from other recent PRs show up as commits on this one. How do I do this cleanly?
oops - I'm assuming that wasn't the right way to go about this. It now builds correctly with current mathlib, but I'm worried I've messed this PR up.
I have no idea what you managed to do, but I'll try to reverse it!

So far I got it to the last-known-good version (I was able to figure that out from the e-mail notifications for this PR). I'm about to merge master, using the command `git pull --no-rebase origin master`.

Ok, I think it's in the state you want it to be in.

To continue working locally, here are steps you can do. Make sure you're on the `matroid_constructions` branch, and then:
```
git fetch
git reset --hard origin/matroid_constructions
```
This will delete any changes you have made in the meantime. This `git reset` is a way to `git pull` without trying to merge my changes with whatever state your local version of `matroid_constructions` is in.

> Ok, I think it's in the state you want it to be in.
> 
> To continue working locally, here are steps you can do. Make sure you're on the `matroid_constructions` branch, and then:
> 
> ```
> git fetch
> git reset --hard origin/matroid_constructions
> ```
> 
> This will delete any changes you have made in the meantime. This `git reset` is a way to `git pull` without trying to merge my changes with whatever state your local version of `matroid_constructions` is in.

Thank you! I know you're too busy for nonsense like this, so I really appreciate it.

No problem. Here are the steps I used, to reset the situation and to make use of your work:
```
# Using the commit id from an e-mail
# (luckily I had this commit locally since I did `git fetch` recently)
git reset --hard 77ff61d
# Reset the branch on github
git push --force
# Pull master, use merging (rather than rebasing)
# I should have my git configured to do this by default, but I never got around to it.
git pull --no-rebase origin master
# Copy your fixes (using the commit id from an e-mail)
git cherry-pick e1c6651
# Check everything works
lake exe cache get
lake build
# Then push
git push
```

### Import summary

No significant changes to the import graph

Thanks!

bors r+

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9421642150/job/25956154762)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9422261530/job/25958131828)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9422261530/job/25958132340)
Seems OK modulo these comments.
I think that names `emptyOn`, `loopyOn`, `freeOn`, and `uniqueBaseOn` are good to go. Each definition also match the comments.
I think that names `emptyOn`, `loopyOn`, `freeOn`, and `uniqueBaseOn` are good to go. Each definition also match the comments.
Seems OK modulo these comments.

```suggestion
/-- The `Matroid α` with empty ground set-/
def emptyOn (α : Type*) : Matroid α :=
  Matroid.ofBaseOfFinite finite_empty (· = ∅) ⟨_, rfl⟩ (by rintro _ _ rfl; simp) (by simp)
```
I'm not sure about the name `trivial` here. Usually the trivial matroid is `loopyOn E`, or the uniform matroid of rank 0. I also couldn't come up with a nice name for this matroid, though.
What about `uniqueBaseMatroidOn`?
or `oneBaseMatroidOn`
How about `uniqueBaseOn`? Since other two newly introduced definitions do not include the term `Matroid` in its name, the third name should also follow that rule I guess.
This lemma seems like it should go in Matroid/Basic, right after `Matroid.ground_nonempty`

```suggestion
/-- The `Matroid α` with empty ground set. -/
```
I'm not sure I would make this one be a `@[simp]` lemma.
I wouldn't make this one be a `@[simp]` lemma. The RHS isn't simpler, and it also duplicates `M`.

```suggestion
  ⟨fun h ↦ ⟨loopyOn_indep_iff.mp h.indep, h.subset_ground⟩,
```
I also probably wouldn't make this be a `@[simp]` lemma.
Another I suggest not making `@[simp]`. One other reason I don't like these kinds in the simp set is that this does not apply in the `freeOn E = M` direction.

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem uniqueBaseOn_self (I : Set α) : uniqueBaseOn I I = freeOn I := by
```

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem uniqueBaseOn_empty (I : Set α) : uniqueBaseOn ∅ I = loopyOn I := by
```

I think the naming convention would suggest
```suggestion
@[simp] theorem restrict_empty (M : Matroid α) : M ↾ (∅ : Set α) = emptyOn α := by
```

```suggestion

This file defines some very elementary examples of matroids, namely those with at most one base.
```

There's a chance you don't want this one as a `@[simp]` lemma, since you'd rather use `uniqueBaseOn_restrict` if you have that hypothesis available, and I'm not sure there are any simp lemmas that say `I ∩ R ∩ E = I ∩ R` if `I ⊆ E`, so you would lose confluence by including it.

Do you need the parentheses?
```suggestion
def loopyOn (E : Set α) : Matroid α := emptyOn α ↾ E
```

```suggestion
theorem eq_loopyOn_iff : M = loopyOn E ↔ M.E = E ∧ ∀ X ⊆ M.E, M.Indep X → X = ∅ := by
```

```suggestion
    fun h ↦ by obtain ⟨B, hB⟩ := M.exists_base; rwa [← h B hB.subset_ground B hB Subset.rfl]⟩
```

Or like this?
```suggestion
def uniqueBaseOn (I E : Set α) : Matroid α := freeOn I ↾ E
```
I suspect you'll have a merge conflict here; please merge master

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Data/Matroid/Constructions): simple constructions of matroids
